title: Overview of Single-Cell and Spatial Multi-Omics Studies in Various Diseases
abstract: This document provides an overview of studies utilizing single-cell and spatial multi-omics technologies across a range of diseases. It highlights the technologies used, the model organisms studied, and the main findings in areas such as cell atlas construction, pathway identification, novel target discovery, immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs), adoptive cell transfer (ACT), host-microbe interactions, infectious diseases, cardiovascular disease, and neurological and brain diseases. The studies reveal insights into disease mechanisms, potential therapeutic targets, and responses to treatments.

sections.heading: Cell atlases construction
sections.content: The study highlighted the transformative potential of single-cell and spatial genomics in understanding disease mechanisms, and diagnosing, and treating various conditions. Constructing a human brain organoid development atlas to investigate the regulation of cell fate decisions.

sections.heading: Ovarian cancer (OC)
sections.content: A single-cell landscape of the OC ecosystem was depicted and revealed the heterogeneity of functional phenotypes and developmental origins of macrophages in tumor tissues and ascites.

sections.heading: Developmental biology
sections.content: A new technology, Camallia-seq, enabled integrative analysis of chromatin accessibility, DNA methylation, transcriptome, as well as cell lineage information, bringing new insights into how cell fate decisions are regulated and how cell identities are maintained under different modalities. Precisely characterizing human embryonic limb development over time and space.

sections.heading: Pathways identification
sections.content: MP6 tumor cells interact with CAFs to shape an immune exclusionary microenvironment via the FABP5-mediated TGFβ pathway. FOXA2 is a critical driver of the adeno-to-neuroendocrine lineage transition in prostate cancer that can activate the KIT pathway to maintain cancer cell proliferation. The Nfix-Ifi27 pathway can cause kidney fibrosis by promoting apoptosis.

sections.heading: Novel targets discovery
sections.content: A HOX-PBX gene regulatory network controlled the survival of LAM cells. A TCF4-dependent regulatory network orchestrated multiple transcriptional programs leading to immunotherapy resistance. TNFRSF18, associated with non-response to anti-PD-1 therapy was highly expressed in T&NK cells within MPLCs.

sections.heading: ICIs
sections.content: Re-emerged clonotypes in ISG-15+CD8+ T cells after treatment among EBV (+) patients were detected and associated with effector T population expressing CXCL13 in responsive EBV (+) tumor, indicating their significant importance in tumor immunochemotherapy response. Identifying distinct CD4+ and CD8+ T cell states within bladder tumors and highlighting the presence of cytotoxic CD4+ T cells and various CD8+ T cell subsets. TdLN-TTSM cells were primary memory T cells that respond to ICI treatment, representing the adoptive transfer of these cells as a promising immunotherapy approach.

sections.heading: ACT
sections.content: Lack of TH2 functionality might be the cause of relapse in CAR-T treatment. A phenotypic signature based on CD39 and CXCL13 identified neoantigen-reactive T cells in fresh NSCLC.

sections.heading: Host-microbe interactions
sections.content: P. fungorum inhibited tumor growth through alanine, aspartate, and glutamate metabolism. Streptococcus anginosus promoted gastric tumorigenesis. The commensal bacterium Lactobacillus johnsonii enhanced the efficacy of ICI therapy by modulating the stemness of CD8+ T cells.

sections.heading: Infectious diseases
sections.content: Discovery and characterization of potent neutralizing antibodies from individuals with Omicron breakthrough infections. A systematical depiction of the immune landscape after vaccinating lipid nanoparticle-mRNA. Observing unique dynamics in the behavior of specific CD8+ T cells during the recuperation phase from COVID-19, among patients suffering from gastrointestinal sequelae.

sections.heading: Cardiovascular disease
sections.content: Constructing the human cardiac landscape and paving the way for the anatomy and immunology of the heart. TCR-M cells expressing Treg markers like Foxp3, Il2ra, and Ctla4 suppressed cardiac immune responses post-MI and improved cardiac function. Deciphering the immune landscapes in the plaques of AS and uncovering immune alterations related to clinical cardiovascular events.

sections.heading: Neurological and brain disease
sections.content: Identifying two disease-associated factors, BRN2 and PTN, which promoted neurogenesis, with PTN also inhibited apoptosis. Two microglial subclusters, ischemic core-associated microglia (ICAM) and ischemic penumbra-associated microglia (IPAM) were identified in the brains of mice subjected to middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO). LGALS9-CD44 is a crucial pathway after ischemic injury. LGALS9 and CD44 exhibited opposite effects, in which upregulation of LGALS9 favored recovery from post-ischemic injury, whereas knockdown of CD44 diminished the therapeutic effect of LGALS9.
